abstract: Johnson & Johnson said  it believed that some of its foreign units had made improper payments related to the sale of medical devices in two small-market countries.
snippet: Johnson & Johnson said  it believed that some of its foreign units had made improper payments related to the sale of medical devices in two small-market countries.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson, the drug and consumer products company, said last night that some of its foreign units might have made improper payments related to the sale of medical devices in two “small-market countries.”

headline.main: J.& J. Says Improper Payments Were Made

abstract: Johnson & Johnson, the drug and consumer products company, said last night that some of its foreign units might have made improper payments related to the sale of medical devices in two “small-market countries.” The company also said that the executive responsible for the units, Michael J. Dormer, 55, worldwide chairman of medical devices and diagnostics, had retired.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson, the drug and consumer products company, said last night that some of its foreign units might have made improper payments related to the sale of medical devices in two “small-market countries.” The company also said that the executive responsible for the units, Michael J. Dormer, 55, worldwide chairman of medical devices and diagnostics, had retired.

headline.main: J.& J. Discloses Possibly Improper Payments
